question: How would you frame the Accord, so donors see a locally led, sustainable solution—not a short-term project 'win'?
What concrete asks would you make to shift resources directly (and simply) to parish groups while protecting community control?
When donors push for visibility or speed, how would you negotiate pacing and optics without compromising non-negotiables?
After a late attempt to weaken local voice (exclusivity/app-only/non-voting), how would you re-engage donors to reinforce equity clauses?
Map the most influential actors in this scenario; who do you approach first and why?
What behind-the-scenes steps would you take with skeptics (brokers, shellers, officials) before going public?
How would you anticipate and manage spoilers (rival councillors, election-season restrictions) while retaining access to decision rooms?
What signals would trigger you to update the power map, and how would that change your engagement plan?
In public fora, how will you ensure farmer representatives (women, youth, PWD) are the primary voices?
How will you structure media/donor interactions so credit stays local and CARE remains in a background support role?
What coaching or prep would you provide to local spokespeople to handle tough questions?
If pressured for CARE to front the effort, how would you respond while preserving local ownership?
What light-touch governance would you set up to balance inclusion and decisiveness?
How would you guarantee meaningful participation (not tokenism) for women, youth, and PWD?
What norms/tools would you use to document decisions and share minutes transparently across the coalition?
If conflict emerges inside the coalition, how do you resolve it without losing momentum on the Accord?
How would you co-create Lusoga talking points that make sense to farmers, buyers, and local leaders at the same time?
Which themes (dignity, safety, predictability, fair weighing) would you elevate for each audience, and why?
With elections approaching, how would you keep the tone neutral yet persuasive?
What specific channels would you use to reach marginalized groups (e.g., youth shellers, PWD) and close the rumor gaps?
What local data would you prioritize collecting, and how would you verify it?
How would you ensure informed consent (opt-in in Lusoga, easy withdrawal) and ethical data handling?
How would you package evidence for different rooms (LC3, community, donors) without releasing raw notes to the media?
If the coalition’s evidence is challenged, how would you validate methods and protect sources?
Without formal authority, how would you secure LC3 agenda time for farmer reps and ACTIVE MINDS?
What backstage diplomacy can CARE do that doesn’t eclipse local leaders?
How would you build trust with cautious officials (e.g., police limits on gatherings) to keep pathways open?
If access to LC3 is blocked, what alternative influence routes would you pursue (co-chairs, neutral venues, phased dialogues)?
What’s your top five risk register for this context, and how will you monitor each item?
What practical safeguards (consent scripts, small meetings, safe wording) will you put in place for women and youth?
How will you run rapid local feedback loops (e.g., priest’s Lusoga voice notes, 'you said / we did' updates)?
If political or donor pressure threatens non-negotiables, how will you adapt communications while holding the red lines?
